Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Exploring the relation between four-dimensional and two-dimensional quantum field theories
Award.AbstractNarration:
The interactions of elementary particles are described using a framework called quantum field theory. When particles interact weakly, precise calculations can be made which agree with experimental results. However, a satisfactory theoretical understanding of the dynamics of strongly-interacting particles - such as the binding of quarks to form a proton - is still lacking. This problem becomes much more tractable in quantum field theories with supersymmetry, in which many exact computations can be made. This research will focus on recently-discovered relations between supersymmetric quantum field theories in four dimensions and a class of quantum field theories in two dimensions. Such relations are very useful, as computations which are very difficult in the four-dimensional theory often become simple and algorithmic in the two-dimensional theory. This research will study a generalization of a well-known 4d/2d relation, which will lead to new 4d/2d pairs. Understanding more examples - and the mathematical structures involved - should help lead to an algorithm to construct 4d/2d pairs. This research will be done in collaboration with Professor Yuji Tachikawa, a leading expert in the field, at the University of Tokyo, Japan.

Specifically, this project will study the instanton partition function of 4d N=2 supersymmetric gauge theory, with gauge group SU(N), in the presence of a surface operator, labeled by a partition of N. It has been conjectured that, in the pure gauge theory, the instanton partition function is equal to the norm of a certain coherent state in the Verma module of a W-algebra, obtained by the quantum Drinfeld-Sokolov reduction corresponding to the same partition of N, of the affine sl(N) Lie algebra. This conjecture will be checked, by explicit computation, for examples which have not yet been studied. This project will also extend the correspondence to quiver gauge theories. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interactions of elementary particles are described by a quantum field theory called the "standard model". This model has been verified experimentally by decades of research at particle colliders. However, many experimental results, such as the confinement of quarks inside of a proton, are very hard to prove mathematically. These questions becomes tractable in quantum field theories with supersymmetry. Due to the existence of supersymmetry, the mathematics involved becomes greatly simplified, and exact information can be obtained which is valid at strong-coupling. This is often possible as many of these theories enjoy dualities where, at strong-coupling, they admit an alternative description as a (possibly different) weakly-coupled theory, in which standard perturbative techniques may be employed in calculations. An understanding of these dualities is usually achieved by realizing the quantum field theories of interest as certain limits of string / M-theory.

 

In this project, I studied the properties of a large class of four-dimensional supersymmetric theories which arise by compactifying six-dimensional theories, which arise in string theory, on a two-dimensional surface. For these theories, dualities can be understood as different ways of decomposing this two-dimensional surface into pairs of pants. Due to the six-dimensional construction, this class of theories enjoys "2d/4d relations" in which properties of the 4d theory can be related to those of a certain 2d theory defined on the surface described above. In this project, I used these relations to study the superconformal index of these theories, which contains exact information about the theories, which is valid at strong-coupling. Using these results, my collaborators and I classified the building blocks of a large family of new supersymmetric quantum field theories in four dimensions, and studied some applications of these results. I expect that these results will lead to much future research devoted to studying the detailed properties of these new theories. Additionally, these theories may be generalized to models with less supersymmetry, which may be viable for phenomenology. Finally, the mathematical structures underlying our results should be of interest to mathematicians working in algebraic geometry and representation theory.
